thread.title: While kids continue to die, we teach them where to hide
thread.title_full: While kids continue to die, we teach them where to hide - Chicago Tribune

author: Heidi Stevens
title: While kids continue to die, we teach them where to hide
text:
Thursday morning, roughly four hours before a gunman started mowing down students at Umpqua Community College, my daughter told me about the lockdown drill that took place the previous day at her elementary school.
Lockdown drills are routine in a way that tornado drills were when I was a kid, which means she often doesn't even mention when they take place.
But my son was talking that morning about a bus drill he completed with his first grade class — "In case there's ever a bomb on the bus," he told us — and that reminded my daughter, 9, of the previous day's events.
The principal got on the school intercom, she said, and announced "Code L! Code L! Code L!" The kids got up from their desks and hid in their cubbies. The teacher locked the door and demanded complete silence.
My kids have been doing these drills since preschool. They talk about them in animated, but not necessarily traumatized, tones.
My son used to think it was hilarious to cram himself into a large bathroom with his 19 preschool classmates, plus three teachers.
My daughter's favorite lockdowns were in first grade, because they could hide in a soundproof room off their main classroom, which meant their teacher could very quietly read to them to calm their nerves.
"Our door isn't soundproof this year," my daughter tells me. "So we have to be silent, so the gunman can't hear us."
Photo gallery: At least nine people were killed in a shooting Oct. 1, 2015, at Umpqua Community College in Roseburg, Oregon.
This is madness. Unacceptable, and yet completely accepted, madness.
My children are lucky. I am lucky. We are a family who has been spared from gun violence. We are surrounded by it daily in our city and almost monthly in our nation's schools, but my children have not been shot.
Far, far too many have. One murdered child would have been too many. We've reached the hundreds .
Not a single morning goes by that I don't drop my son and daughter at school and wonder for a split second — that's all I allow myself — whether they will be murdered by a gunman that day.
I know I'm not the only parent who does that.
We have become like the sea turtles who entwine pollutants into their nests — accepting and weaving deadly trash into the most sacred parts of our lives.
"Somehow this has become routine," President Barack Obama said Thursday. "The conversation in the aftermath of it — we've become numb to this."

(Tribune wire reports) He's exactly right, of course. And that's shameful.
Even worse, though, is that our children don't know any different. At 6 and 9, my kids haven't known a school year without lockdowns, and they likely never will.
They know gunmen routinely open fire on classrooms, and they know students routinely die.
And they know all we're doing about it is teaching them where to hide.
That fills me with more shame and sorrow than I know what to do with.
And I'm one of the lucky parents.
